Hi! I'm a computer science major with an interest in design.

As a software engineer with a focus in front-end development, I'm passionate about user accessibility and designing applications to be as simple and user-friendly as possible. Along with this, I love working on projects that somehow give back to the community in some shape or form.

In my free time, I enjoy hiking and hanging out with my cat. I even have a personal goal of trying to visit every national park in the U.S.

It's nice to meet you!

Weather Forecaster

A single-page application showcasing the average temperature and daily forecast for a given city so that users can check the weather no matter what city or degrees their location is in.

Position

Front-end Developer @ Credera

Project

Internal Recruiment Initiative

Timeline

7 Days

Tools Used

Figma

React.js

Open-Meteo API

OpenCage GeoCoding API

Problem Overview

This was support for Credera's internal initiative for hiring front-end developers for their Experienced Design practice. I was tasked with developing and testing the interview assessments that would be given to new graduate and experienced candidates in order to provide feedback from a fresh pair of eyes and a new perspective.


This task included using React.js and open sourced APIs such as Open-Meteo and OpenCage Geocoding, in order to streamline and filter data when recreating the assesment. I also was tasked with building upon the assessment in order to enhance the experience, and was challenged with giving feedback on what could be improved, what was challenging, and testing technical issues within the code base.

My Impact

  • Tested and programmed initial interview process (recreating this weather forecaster) for potential Front-end developers through React.js in order to provide feedback on what could be improved, added, or enhanced in the interview process.
  • Provided internal initiatives for improving candidate filtering and led design initiatives aimed at fostering a seamless onboarding experience for new hires.
  • Built vision, ran user research, and defined product framework using Figma, React.js, and API design.

Salsa Shooter

An interactive virtual reality rhythm game aimed to teach Puerto Rican culture and the influece of Salsa music

Position

Developer

Project

VR School Project

Timeline

April 2022 - May 2022

Tools Used

Oculus Quest 2

Unreal Engine

Audio Mixer

Blender

C++

Problem Overview

Create an immersive and educational virtual reality experience that would teach a cultural aspect from any culture.


This was the final project for my virtual reality class at Texas A&M that focused on Puerto Rican culture and the significance that Salsa and Samba music has in this heritage.

My Impact

  • Developed and designed game play and game mechanics using C++ in Unreal Engine and the Oculus Quest 2.
  • Pototyped and aided in game environment development and environment testing through Unreal Engine in order to stress test and improve game stability/performance.
  • Researched and integrated audio synchronization and audio mixing into game play in order to accomplish the rhythm playing aspect and the Salsa/Samba music aspect.
×

Bridges

A mobile application that translates a given spoken langauge into a given sign langauge and vice-versa, in order to mediate the conversation gap between the deaf and the hearing.

Position

Product Designer

Project

Self-Initiative

Timeline

7 Days

Tools Used

Figma

Adobe Illustrator

Spline

Vectary

Problem Overview

As the sole designer of this project, I was able to choose a problem at my discretion and decided to pay attention to the daily issues that the deaf community faces.


For the deaf and sign language community there is limited availability of up-to-date, high-quality resources that incorporate technological advancements for sign language. Users often struggle to find accessible and comprehensive tools that keep pace with advancements in sign language recognition and accurate translation, hindering their ability to effectively learn and communicate to the outside world. Along with this, there is an existing langauge barrier between households with deaf children and hearing parents, or vice-versa.


I wanted to design a solution that would both mediate this language gap between the deaf and hearing, while also providing a convenient tool for these user's to apply in their daily lives by incorporating machine learning and computer vision to accurately recognize and interpret a variety of languages in real time.


Design Process

Initial Thinking

Target Users

  • Users that are deaf or hard of hearing
  • Users that are mute
  • Users that are hearing and want to communicate with the deaf

Research Methods

  • Research online
  • Competitive analysis
  • User interviews

Desk Research

Scanning research studies and web articles about existing langauge barriers for the deaf community revealed:

  • Around 2-3 out of 1000 children are born with a detectable level of hearing loss in one or both ears.
  • More than 90% of deaf children are born to hearing parents while 5-10% of deaf children are born to deaf parents.
  • The reality of everyday communication for a deaf child using sign langauge in a hearing family is limited as a common mode of communcation does not exist for many of these families.

Competitive Analysis

Hand Talk, Pocket Sign, and We Sign were three top competitors I found available in the sign language app market. Below I will highlight the gaps or pain points that each app has:

The competition either presented poor UX, non-intuitive user interface design, or lacked real time video translation. Many of these were also designated for a 1-to-1 langauge translation rather than being multi-lingual.


The gap?

A multi-lingual solution specifically centered around achieving all three modes of sign langauge translation (sign, voice, video).


User Interview

I conducted 5 user interviews to learn more about the deaf and hearing community, and how they typically communicate with those around them in their daily routine. I was able to gather my pool of candidates by visiting my local community sign langauge school.


My recruiment criteria was based off of demographic and behavior. I was looking for an even mix of people who were hard of hearing or experienced hearing loss and how this affected their lives. I was also looking for users that were mute/deaf, ideally people that worked full-time jobs or were students, and lastly a small group of people that were hearing.


From these interviews, I wanted to gain more insight on the target users and ensure that I was designing something that would genuinly meet their needs, rather than something that would only have met my own.

Research Findings / Pain Points

  • It's challenging to find one common language amongst the hearing and deaf, as not everyone has the time or means to learn sign langauge. A persistant langauge barrier exists between the two communities.
  • Finding a multi-lingual sign language translation app has yet to be created or popularized as many sign langauge apps translate from a one-to-one basis.
  • The user interface for many sign langauge apps is not pleasing to the eye or user intutive.

Problem Statement

Sketches

Wireframe

Design Decision

Q. What is the most efficient digital platform?


A. Mobile Application


The use of a mobile platform allows for easy and increased accessibility when using the app as it provides instant access to the app's services anywhere, anytime. It is an excellent platform for using on the go and aids in increasing user app utilization. According to key mobile app statistics, studies show that 70% of all US digital media time comes from mobile apps.
